DOC.HEAD: Eastern Airlines Reducing Schedule
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines, which just sold its Latin American routes, also is cutting back some domestic flights, the company said Friday. In the first announced reduction of its flight schedule since Eastern began rebuilding from a crippling strike, the carrier said it will reduce daily flights from 830 to 803 on Jan. 31. Among the reductions are cuts in nonstop service from Miami to Boston, Philadelphia, Orlando, Tampa and several Caribbean cities. That will reduce Eastern's departures from its Miami home base from 78 to 51, with deeper cuts ahead next year when the sale of Latin American routes to American Airlines is completed. In a message to employees this week, Eastern said ``some furloughs may be necessary as we reduce operations.'' ``It's a reflection of the revamping we're in the process of doing on the current operation, which is going to involve a return to the basics of the business plan that was presented in April,'' company spokesman Robin Matell said Friday. ``We're trying to develop the best possible schedule that opens the most potential for profitability.'' Hobbled by the strike of its three unions that began March 4, Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five days later and in April said it would rebuild as a carrier about two-thirds its pre-strike size. Negotiations to sell its Central and South American routes to rival American stalled in August, and Eastern officials said they would keep that service and build back to 90 percent of Eastern's pre-strike size. However, projected cash shortfalls displeased some Eastern creditors, and the company and its parent Texas Air Corp. this week sold the Latin routes and other assets to American. Eastern will continue operating the routes until the deal obtains approval from the Department of Transportation and U.S. bankruptcy court, expected to take as much as six months. However, the carrier is going ahead with other adjustments back to the plan for operations two-thirds that of its pre-strike size, Matell said. Eastern had more than 30,000 employees and 1,040 daily flights before the strike. The company has about 20,000 workers, mostly non-union, now. Matell said no layoffs of pilots, flight attendants or mechanics are anticipated. American, the nation's largest airline, has said it will absorb Eastern's employees in Latin America when it takes over the routes. Officials of the Machinists union, the lone union still striking against Eastern, said Eastern's planes are flying at less than half capacity, despite the carrier's sharp fare discounting in hopes of luring back passengers. Matell said Eastern's flights have been at about 50 percent for the first half of December, but were picking up for the holidays. At Machinists Local 702, strikers and their families gathered Friday evening for a Christmas party, with Santa Claus handing out gifts donated from the AFL-CIO and several other national unions, local President Frank Ortis said. ``We're going to have a happy Christmas after all, despite the Scrooge (Chairman) Frank Lorenzo,'' Ortis said.
